author: Web desk
title: 'Courts have exposed BJP‚Äôs conspiracy‚Äô: AAP on Kejriwal‚Äôs bail - The Week
text:
The Aam Aadmi Party welcomed the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision to grant interim bail to Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal in the liquor policy case and said the BJP should stop hatching conspiracies against opposition parties.
Addressing presspersons, Delhi Minister Atishi said the Bharatiya Janata Party hatched a conspiracy to stop Kejriwal‚Äôs release from prison, hence they got him arrested by the Central Bureau of Investigation. ‚ÄúBJP knew Arvind Kejriwal has been granted bail by the Rouse Avenue Court, they know that he will get bail from the Supreme Court too. That is why, they hatched another conspiracy and the day on which the bail hearing was scheduled in Supreme Court, they made CBI arrest Arvind Kejriwal a day before that.‚Äù ‚ÄúOne after the other, every court in this country has exposed your conspiracy, every court is granting bail to Arvind Kejriwal. I would like to tell the BJP, end your arrogance and stop hatching conspiracy against other parties. Truth can be troubled but not defeated,‚Äù Atishi added. AAP National General Secretary and Rajya Sabha MP Sandeep Pathak termed the court order "historic" and alleged that the excise policy case was a "circus" by the BJP. He said the SC order is very ‚Äúsoothing‚Äù. Delhi Minister Saurabh Bharadwaj said the Prevention of Money Laundering Act is a black law and the party is hopeful that Kejriwal will also be granted bail in the excise policy case filed by the CBI. The Supreme Court granted interim bail to Kejriwal in the money laundering case registered in connection with an alleged liquor policy scam. However, Kejriwal was not released from Tihar jail as he has been remanded in a connected case registered by CBI.

author: BOB JACOBbjacob@cjn.org
title: Despite war, Gross Schechter eighth graders head to Israel
text: School trips to Israel are memorable in many ways, but for the eighth-grade class at Gross Schechter Day School in Pepper Pike, this year‚Äôs trip promises to be like no other. That‚Äôs because many schools across the country canceled their annual trips due to the Israel-Hamas war. As the students prepared to depart from Cleveland Hopkins International Airport on May 5 for a three-week stay in Eretz Yisrael, the school marked the trip with an 8th Grade Nesiyah Tova, which means ‚Äúhave a good trip; bon voyage,‚Äù on May 3 at the school. As the eighth-grade class sat on stage, students heard remarks from Head of School Ginny Galili; board president Erica Lazzaro; Randy Boroff, director of academics; Rabbi Ben Shlimovitz, middle school Judaic studies teacher/coordinator of Jewish living; and Sheri Gross, director of creative programming. Director of Judaic studies Elana Perlin offered a d‚Äôvar Torah before the eighth graders received presentations from the other grades and sweatshirts for their trip. Rabbi Scott Roland of Congregation Shaarey Tikvah in Beachwood offered a tefillat haderekh and birkat kohanim as the travelers huddled under a tallit. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs extremely important that Gross Schechter Day School‚Äôs eighth-grade class goes to Israel because annually this is the capstone event of the Gross Schechter student‚Äôs journey from early childhood to middle school,‚Äù Galili told the Cleveland Jewish News. ‚ÄúBefore they graduate to high school, it‚Äôs extremely important they strengthen their relationship with Israel and Israeli people, that they grow in their understanding of Israel and in their understanding of the complexities that Israel and the Israeli people face.‚Äù Galili said unlike previous trips, these students will perform more volunteer work in the aftermath of the Oct. 7, 2023, surprise attack by Hamas that killed 1,200 Israelis and saw 250 people taken hostage, and lead into the war, which is now in its seventh month. The students will ‚Äúincrease the amount of volunteerism and service that the eighth graders will engage in alongside their Israeli brothers and sisters,‚Äù Galili said. ‚ÄùIt will have even more of a mission, a theme of solidarity with Israel and the Israeli people. ...‚Äù The students visiting Israel are Isabella Bodzin, Dalia Epstein, Shay-Lee Hameiri, Lyla Levin, Avery Milota and Miriam Shapiro, who are joined by chaperones Lauren Henkin, middle school coordinator and language arts teacher, and Binyamin Kleinman, middle school Judaics teacher. For ‚Äúthe eighth graders who are going to Israel, this year is an extremely meaningful trip,‚Äù Lazzaro told the CJN. ‚ÄúTo have Gross Schechter as the only Jewish day school in Cleveland sending a class of eighth graders really shows as a testament to how important Israel is to our curriculum and to our students and to our parents.‚Äù

author: @theinquisitr
title: Lauren S√°nchez's Killer Legs Once Owned the Spotlight-Now They're Competing With Her 'Botoxed' Face
text:
In June, Lauren S√°nchez tied the knot with Jeff Bezos in a wedding fit for royalty. A-listers, fireworks, the works. But no amount of extravagance could outshine the buzz around something else entirely: her face. The ceremony was dripping with glamor, and enough headlines to last the month. But even as the couple basked in the spotlight, one thing kept trailing S√°nchez like a shadow. Speculation around her ever-changing face.
From plumper lips to what looks like tweaks to her nose and cheeks, internet sleuths have been poring over before-and-after pictures like it‚Äôs a national sport. Some also believe she may have opted for a bit of skin tightening to keep her look extra polished. Her facial transformation has sparked so much chatter that many have completely forgotten another of her once-iconic features , those killer legs.
Which Lauren Sanchez version do you prefer?
I vote Before/Natural!
üëçüèªüëçüèªüëçüèªüëçüèª üëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèª pic.twitter.com/dhMXtzJR3n
‚Äî üá∫üá∏ùêìùê°ùêû ùêÜùê®ùêùùêüùêöùê≠ùê°ùêûùê´üáÆüáπ (@Godfatherparte2) July 2, 2025
 Believe it or not , before cosmetic talk took over the narrative, it was Lauren S√°nchez‚Äôs legs that made headlines. Way back in 2004, when she graced the red carpet at the 15th annual GLAAD Media Awards , the focus wasn‚Äôt her face. It was those standout stems. Photos from the event still live rent-free on the internet, showing S√°nchez in a sleeveless black dress, cut just high enough to give her legs a red carpet moment of their own.
With media personalities and celebs swarming the event, S√°nchez still managed to draw eyes. Her toned and sculpted legs looked like they belonged in a fitness ad. And the way she posed? Like she knew she had the kind of legs that didn‚Äôt need any help from filters or enhancements. They did the talking.
 View this post on Instagram
A post shared by Oprah Daily (@oprahdaily)
 Fast-forward to now, and while her face may be the center of debate , her legs? They‚Äôve barely changed, and if anything, they might be stronger. The proof came when she landed a photoshoot for Elle magazine‚Äôs cover, celebrating an all-female crew headed for space. The image was shared by Oprah Daily on Instagram, showing S√°nchez alongside Katy Perry, Gayle King, and others. But even in that star-studded lineup, her legs still held their own. Strong, lean, and every bit as camera-ready as they were twenty years ago.
Of course, it‚Äôs tough for her iconic legs to completely steal the spotlight when her facial evolution has made her almost unrecognizable in older pictures. But in fairness, those legs have aged like fine wine. And even if her look has changed, her lower half continues to serve the same energy it did back in the day.
One thing‚Äôs for sure. While S√°nchez‚Äôs face has sparked rumors, her legs have remained headline-worthy, then and now.

author: ArcaMax Publishing, Inc.
title: New Year's risk? San Jose experiencing 3rd highest COVID wave ever right now, wastewater shows
text:
As the countdown to 2024 approaches, Dwayne Taylor ‚Äî the founder of San Jose events company Taylor Productions ‚Äî is preparing to celebrate. For nearly a decade, he has hosted one of the city‚Äôs largest New Year‚Äôs parties. And for the first time since 2020, COVID-19 is finally feeling like less of an obstacle.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve had it three times, and I‚Äôve also had a lot of really close friends who passed away from COVID,‚Äù said Taylor, who suspended the party in 2020 and 2021 before bringing it back last year. ‚ÄúSo if I thought for a second that this party would be a problem or a spreader event, I would have canceled it in a heartbeat.‚Äù
Despite the persistent presence of COVID-19 and an ongoing surge ‚Äî hospitalizations are up, and so is the virus‚Äô presence in wastewater ‚Äî Taylor is among many Bay Area residents making the same calculus.
Most are throwing masks and other precautions to the winds, and it‚Äôs not just revelers. Nearly four years after the pandemic‚Äôs onset, state- and county-level health warnings are less frequent and more tempered than they‚Äôve ever been, mostly reminding people to get vaccinated, and to stay home when sick.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been struggling in terms of communicating to the public that there‚Äôs a lot of virus out there, there‚Äôs a high chance of getting sick if you don‚Äôt take precautions ‚Ä¶ but at the same time, things are a lot better,‚Äù said John Swartzberg, a clinical professor emeritus of infectious diseases and vaccinology at UC Berkeley‚Äôs School of Public Health.
Across the Bay Area, regions are seeing ‚Äúhigh‚Äù levels of COVID-19 in their wastewater, including San Leandro, Central Contra Costa, Oakland, San Francisco and Redwood City, according to the WastewasterSCAN dashboard, a national data set based at Stanford University.
 San Jose is experiencing a particularly dramatic surge, with wastewater data showing COVID-19 at a level only seen during the two worst waves of the pandemic. Concentration levels are also higher than they were during the first winter wave in January 2021, when hospitals canceled non-emergency surgeries and procedures to ward off a continued spread.
So why aren‚Äôt people worried? Unlike the early days of the pandemic, when contracting COVID was deadly business for the elderly and immunocompromised, and risky for everyone else, new infections less frequently equate to hospitalizations and death. Readily available vaccines have usually rendered cases milder, and therapeutics such as Paxlovid can reduce the severity of symptoms.
Even so, the level of hospitalizations this year is not insignificant, and is much higher than people heading to the emergency room with the flu.
Despite the reduced risk, COVID is still deadly, contributing to more than 1,000 deaths in California since October 1. Between December 10 through 16, 2,800 people were hospitalized for COVID across the state, and just over 1,000 for the flu.

author: Redazione web
title: , Mosca prepara test nuovo missile nucleare
text:
Mosca si starebbe preparando a testare il suo nuovo missile da crociera 9M730 Burevestnik a propulsione nucleare, e dotato di testata nucleare, proprio mentre il presidente Vladimir Putin si appresta a discutere della questione ucraina con il presidente Usa Donald Trump venerd√¨: lo riporta la Reuters sul suo sito, che cita due ricercatori americani e una fonte occidentale esperta di
Starmer incontrer√† il presidente ucraino Zelensky a Londra
Il primo ministro britannico Keir Starmer incontrer√† il presidente ucraino Volodymyr Zelensky a Londra oggi, alla vigilia del vertice tra Donald Trump e Vladimir Putin in Alaska, ha annunciato il suo ufficio.. Starmer, che mercoled√¨ ha parlato di una concreta possibilit√† di raggiungere un cessate il fuoco attraverso la mediazione del presidente degli Stati Uniti, prevede di incontrare il leader ucraino a Downing Street alle 9:30, le 10.30 italiane.
